item.title: Topic 6: Animal Minds
item.description: Reading Descartes, René. 1637/1646. “Descartes on the significance of language.” excerpts from Discourse on the Method and a published letter. (Note that the site says the first excerpt is from Descartes’s Meditations, but it’s actually from the Discourse Part 6. You can see the context of it in the Early Modern Texts version here, where it’s on pages 22–23.) Andrews, Kristin. 2020. Sections 4.3–4.6 of “Consciousness” in The Animal Mind.

item.title: Topic 5: Biological Information
item.description: Do genes function by carrying information, like blueprints for builders? Do they say things? Reading Godfrey-Smith, Peter. 2013. “Information,” Chapter 9 of Philosophy of Biology. Princeton University Press. eBook via Axinn Library (Hofstra login required). Hofstra now provides unlimited access to this title, so you shouldn’t have any problems accessing it, but let me know. Reading questions TBA TBA See also Adriaans, Pieter. 2020. “Information,” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

item.title: Topic 4: Biological Sexes
item.description: Reading Griffiths, Paul. 2020. “Sex is Real.” Aeon. Richardson, Sarah S. 2022. “Sex Contextualism.” Philosophy, Theory, and Practice in Biology 14 (2). doi: https://doi.org/10.3998/ptpbio.2096 Reading questions What conceptions of sex does Griffiths argue against? What conception of sex does Griffiths argue for? What is Griffiths’s argument for his conception of sex? Why are sex chromosomes not sufficient for biological sex? How does Griffiths argue that his conception of biological sex cannot be used to characterize sex in non-biological human institutions?

item.title: Topic 3: Evolution and Ethics
item.description: Reading Darwin, Charles. 1871. Descent of Man, or, Selection in Relation to Sex. short excerpt distributed in class. Wilson, E. O. 1975. Sociobiology: The New Synthesis. short excerpt distributed in class. Kitcher, Philip. 1993. “Four Ways of ‘Biologicizing’ Ethics.” In In Mendel’s mirror: philosophical reflections on biology. Oxford University Press, 2003. Find the eBook through Axinn Library here. Godfrey-Smith, Peter. 2013. “Evolution and Social Behavior,” Chapter 8 of Philosophy of Biology, Princeton University Press.

item.title: Topic 2: Darwin and Natural Selection
item.description: Reading Darwin, Charles. 1859. The Origin of Species. First edition (of 6). Read Chapter 3. Then, read just up to page 10 in Chapter 4, and finally the final paragraph of Chapter 14 (on the last page). Available via Blackboard. Waters, C. Kenneth. 2003. “The Arguments in the Origin of Species.” In The Cambridge Companion to Darwin, edited by Gregory Radick and Jonathan Hodge, 116–139. Cambridge University Press. via Blackboard.

item.title: Topic 1: Before Natural Selection
item.description: Reading Aristotle, excerpts from Physics and Parts of Animals (about 350 BCE). Handout. Available through Blackboard > Course Documents. Note: This is short but dense. Try to work through it carefully; see the reading questions below ↓. William Smellie, “Of the Progressive Scale or Chain of Beings in the Universe” (1791). Available through Blackboard > Course Documents. Note: This is an account of the relationships among all living things from the perspective of late-eighteenth century biology in England.

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Choose one of the following, numbered topic-options, below. Focusing on what it asks for, write at least 1200 words. (Adding in response to questions: There is no upper limit for how many words you write, but there is also not any expectation that you will write much more than the minimum.) Each of the topics has two parts, marked “a” and “b.” They are intended to be thought of as equally important, so devote at least 40% of your writing to each of those two parts.

item.title: First Test Questions
item.description: Our first test will take place during class on March 16. How to study To study for the test review and think about the answers to the Learning Questions for each of our units to date, and try to find the main arguments for each of the readings and/or class presentations. Think about integration among the topics — to how they might be understood as answer to the same, more general questions.

item.title: Interpreting Grades
item.description: This note about grading and interpreting grades just adds some detail to what the course syllabus already says about grading. 4-point scale Grades in this course are assigned and calculated using Hofstra’s 4-point scale (described here in the Hofstra Bulletin). Following the Bulletin, the alphabetical grades, including plus (+) and minus (–), have the following 4-point scale values (and vice versa): letter 4pt Student’s academic performance … A 4.

item.title: Participation Rubric
item.description: This is the participation rubric to be used for grading participation in this course. Read it as saying “A student who demonstrates … earns a grade of X,” where X is the letter grade at the top of the column.1 A B C D F Active role in discussions, drawing on texts Regular, constructive participation drawing on texts Inconsistent constructive participation based on texts Vague comments reflecting limited engagement with texts Persistent lack of engagement with texts Full preparation for approximately every class Substantial preparation, normally Inconsistent evidence of preparation Rare evidence of participation No positive evidence of participation Success at advancing level and depth of discussion, persistently Regular contributions based on assigned material, which sometimes improve discussion and never diminish it Rare or no significant contribution to the level of discussion while not reducing it Activity sometimes diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Activity regularly diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Active engagement with and listening to peers, persistently Sincere efforts to interact with peers, normally Limited engagement with peers Rare interaction with peers No interaction with peers This rubric is significantly based on, and lightly adapted from, one written by another philosophy professor, Jay Odenbaugh.
